title: What's the difference between classic R&B and soul? - Quora

response.answer_text: R&B is a combination of jazz , blues and gospel and occasionally pop and rock . It is an umbrella term to describe this type of music . Soul is a subgenera of R&B and combines R&B and gospel with funk . R&B and Soul have many complex chords while funk has one chord . Funk has repeating beats and less emphasis on vocals while vocals (often with high pitch) have great importance in R&B and soul . Funk is also played in combination with rock and but and some bands made a career out of it. Funk came up in 60s African Americans discovered and excelled at Soul &R&B . There are a few Caucasian artists/bands practicing this genre ( called as Blue eyed soul). Ray Charles , Aretha Franklin, Marvyn Gaye, Stevie Wonder, Diana Ross , Mariah Carey , Curtis Mayfield etc are top R&B /Soul artists and very succesful. Soul/R&B came up in 50s , hit peak popularity in 60–70s and continues to have steady following till date. R&B is a forever musical genre like Rock . J The groups Sly &Family Stone , The Meters, Funkadelic and War are a well known examples of funk music.James Brown played a lot of soul and funk. Jimi Hendrix is the most famous rock artist to have embraced funk. Jam rock band -Grateful Dead often played funk based songs - Notably the songs Franklin Tower and Shakedown Street are based on funk. Phish also plays a lot of funk music Rap/Hip Hop combines R&B with street based culture {rhythm + language/slang+ dance moves } to come up with a contemporary urban musical style that has very popular today

Soul music is a subset of classic R&B. R&B (rhythm & blues) encompasses pretty much all traditionally African-American secular music that is not jazz or hip-hop; that list includes soul music. Traditionally, “classic R&B” is considered everything before about 1980 and everything thereafter is “contemporary R&B” (the split indicated by Michael Jackson’s 1969 album Off the Wall, which is considered to sit at the nexus point of disco, funk, classic R&B, and contemporary R&B) Soul music is a specific type of R&B that draws heavily on the gritty sounds of Black gospel music. Examples include Otis Redding and Aretha Franklin. Their more pop-polished contemporaries like Diana Ross & the Supremes are referred to as soul artists by some, but others have challenged that categorization. Classic R&B also includes doo wop, funk and disco, and classic R&B from the mid-1950s is considered to overlap with early rock and roll (in fact, “rock and roll” was a term invented so that segregated radio stations could play R&B).
